title: Understanding the term 'Domain'
text: The 'Domain' of a function refers to all the possible 'input' values (usually x-values) that the function can take. In a set of ordered pairs, look at the first number in each pair to find the domain.

title: Identifying Ordered Pairs
text: An ordered pair looks like this: (x,y), where $$x$$ is the input and $$y$$ is the output. In the list $$((2,10),(3,10),(4,20),(5,30),(6,40))$$, each number inside the parentheses represents an ordered pair of the form (input,output).

title: Extracting Inputs from Ordered Pairs
text: To find the domain, we need to focus on the 'input' values from each ordered pair in the list. These are found in the first position of each pair. For example, in $$(2,10)$$, the input is $$2$$.

title: Listing the Domain
text: Now that you know the domain consists of the 'input' values, let's list them from each ordered pair. Ideally, list them in ascending order, without repeating any values.
